content.text: When a sentence contains multiple quantifiers, their **scope** — the order in which they appear — can dramatically change the meaning. This is one of the trickiest aspects of quantificational logic.

content.definition: The scope of a quantifier is the part of the formula it governs. In ∀x(P(x) → Q(x)), the universal quantifier has scope over the entire conditional.

content.title: Scope Ambiguity: Everyone Loves Someone
premises: Reading 1: ∀x∃y(Loves(x,y)) — Each person loves at least one person (possibly different for each)
Reading 2: ∃y∀x(Loves(x,y)) — There is someone whom everyone loves (the same person)
content.note: The sentence 'Everyone loves someone' is ambiguous! Reading 1 is true if Alice loves Bob, Carol loves Dave, etc. Reading 2 requires one specific person loved by all.

content.text: The quantifier that appears first (leftmost) has **wide scope** and controls the interpretation. In ∀x∃y(...), for each x we can pick a different y. In ∃y∀x(...), we pick one y that works for all x.

content.title: Another Example: A Number Greater Than All
premises: ∀x∃y(y > x) — For every number, there's a greater one (TRUE for natural numbers)
∃y∀x(y > x) — There's a number greater than all numbers (FALSE — no largest number)
content.note: Same words, opposite truth values! Scope matters enormously.

content.question: What does ∃y∀x(Loves(x,y)) mean?
options: There is someone whom everyone loves
content.explanation: ∃y∀x(Loves(x,y)) says: there exists a y such that for all x, x loves y. In other words, there's one specific person (y) who is loved by everyone.
